--- In junit@y..., Carniel Frederic <frederic.carniel@u...> wrote:
> I trie=
d to sell test first approch on java in my companie with 
junit and
> other=
 tools for servlet testing (we use tomcat and sun jdk).
> The main question=
 is :
> What is the overhead of time for coding test first ?
> Does someone=
 know some comparaison document on time coding between 
standard
> coding a=
nd test first coding ?
> Could you give me a feed back of your experience? =

> does it take more time or the same time ?
> 
> Thank you
> 
> Fr=E9d=E9r=
ic CARNIEL

The clients I have worked with LOVE test first once they really=
 start 
doing it.  It becomes very important to test only things that can 
=
break.  This is the number one argument I see people use against Test 
Firs=
t.  Don't test setters/getters, DB reads and writes, container 
managed per=
sistence, etc. unless they start breaking.  The best way 
to determine thin=
gs are breaking is by having 
acceptance/system/functional/integration test=
s.  If you have a broken 
acceptance test then you are probably missing at =
least one unit test.

As others have pointed out in the long term there is =
no overhead, as 
it cuts down on debugging time so much.  Personally I know=
 that test 
first makes people go faster.  I see this every time I teach a =

class.  Inevitable one or two pairs don't do test first.  These are 
also =
the folks who finish the assignment last (or not at all).

Erik Meade
